Content: While planes fly in refueling formation as shown in the figure, the pilot of the tanker aircraft never adjusts the throttle¹, but the pilot of the receiver aircraft must constantly increase the throttle to keep up with the tanker aircraft.
Air- to- air refueling is used to increase the distance an aircraft can fly. Fuel flows from a tanker aircraft to a receiver aircraft through a device called a boom, as shown in the figure.
References: throttle — A device that controls the flow of fuel or power to an engine.
